word.entryDescription: a thing you wear on your head
word.entryExample: This is my hat.

word.entryDescription: to dislike very much
word.entryExample: I hate waiting at the airport if the plane is delayed.

word.entryDescription: to have a period of time between classes in which you can relax, have lunch, etc
word.entryExample: Why don't we have a break and go for a walk?

word.entryDescription: spend time taking a shower
word.entryExample: I have a shower at 7 o'clock in the morning.

word.entryDescription: must; used to show that it is necessary or very important that something happens in the present or future
word.entryExample: You have to go to school if you are younger than sixteen.

word.entryDescription: an allergy caused by pollen
word.entryExample: I've suffered from hay fever since I was ten.

word.entryDescription: a situation where you can't think very clearly
word.entryExample: I drifted through most of the day in a kind of detached haze.

word.entryDescription: unclear; not exact
word.entryExample: Our routine for the last three days had consisted of little more than slipping in and out of hazy sleep, playing card games and looking forward to the next chicken-and-rice stop.

word.entryDescription: a device which you wear over your ears so that you can listen to music privately
word.entryExample: The music's too loud. Could you use your headphones?

word.entryDescription: the condition of the body
word.entryExample: Good health is very important.

word.entryDescription: services which look after people's health
word.entryExample: What about a job in healthcare?

word.entryDescription: free from illness
word.entryExample: I eat a lot of fruit to be healthy.

word.entryDescription: to sense sound with your ears
word.entryExample: Did you hear the good news?

word.entryDescription: the ability to hear
word.entryExample: My hearing was checked after the heavy metal concert.

word.entryDescription: the part of the body which pumps the blood
word.entryExample: I have a pain in my heart.

word.entryDescription: a sudden serious condition in which your heart stops working properly
word.entryExample: If your blood pressure is high, you're more at risk of a heart attack.

word.entryDescription: extremely sad
word.entryExample: Les Miserables is the most heart-breaking musical I've ever seen.

word.entryDescription: a form of energy that increases with temperature and is transferred from one thing to another
word.entryExample: They take the heat from the sun in summer and stay warm in winter.

word.entryDescription: to make something hot or warm
word.entryExample: We usually eat meals that we can quickly heat up in a microwave.

word.entryDescription: the system that warms a building
word.entryExample: If you are cold put on the central heating.

word.entryDescription: a period of excessively hot weather
word.entryExample: When a heatwave occurs many people tend to become bad-tempered.

word.entryDescription: weighing a lot
word.entryExample: These chairs are really heavy. What are they made of?

word.entryDescription: an outstanding scene; an amazing scene to see (said with emphasis)
word.entryExample: It was one heck of a scene.

word.entryDescription: a small brown mammal whose back is covered in spines, and which rolls up into a ball when it is afraid
word.entryExample: There's a hedgehog in the garden.

word.entryDescription: a particular distance above the ground
word.entryExample: You can measure height and length with a tape measure or a ruler.

word.entryDescription: past simple and past participle form of 'hold' – to cause to take place; carry on
word.entryExample: Oh yes, concerts are held twice a week and the restaurants have a great atmosphere.

word.entryDescription: an aircraft with long blades on the top which turn round quickly to make it fly
word.entryExample: People who fly planes and helicopters are called pilots.

word.entryDescription: a person who operates the controls of a helicopter
word.entryExample: He flies a helicopter. He's a helicopter pilot.

word.entryDescription: something you say to greet somebody
word.entryExample: Hello, my name is Sam.

word.entryDescription: a hard item worn on the head to protect it
word.entryExample: Shall I bring the helmet for your bike?

word.entryDescription: to make it easier for someone to do something by doing some of it yourself, or by giving them something
word.entryExample: Can you help me put this suitcase on the top shelf?

word.entryDescription: a department of a company that people call for help when they are having problems with a computer
word.entryExample: The IT help desk is busy answering calls.

word.entryDescription: to help somebody, especially beacuse they are busy or in a difficult situation
word.entryExample: Have you helped out in your community or done something for a family member or a neighbour?

word.entryDescription: someone who helps somebody; assistant
word.entryExample: The carpenter's helper brought in the tools.

word.entryDescription: (of a person) willing to help
word.entryExample: The man I spoke to was very helpful and gave me some good advice.

word.entryDescription: a small plant used to add flavour to food
word.entryExample: Put the onion in the frying pan with the herbs and spices.

word.entryDescription: to or at this place
word.entryExample: Tim, can you come here for a second?

word.entryDescription: somebody, particularly a man, who is admired for doing something brave or for achieving something of importance
word.entryExample: I heard that Harrison Ford, the actor who played a hero in the original Star Wars film, was in the hospital near my school.

word.entryDescription: used to refer to the female who is affected by an action when she also performs the action
word.entryExample: She's fallen off her bicycle and hurt herself.

word.entryDescription: the time when somebody/something had most power or success, or was most popular
word.entryExample: In their heyday they produced 3,000 tonnes of silver for the ancient Athenians.

word.entryDescription: something informal you say to greet somebody
word.entryExample: Hi, how are you?

word.entryDescription: a long way above the ground
word.entryExample: What's the highest mountain in the world?

word.entryDescription: at a high degree; advanced
word.entryExample: We expected a high level of care, but were very disappointed.

word.entryDescription: shoes with high heels
word.entryExample: I always wear my high-heeled boots and I love chunky jewellery.

word.entryDescription: the comparative form of 'high' – a long way above the ground
word.entryExample: That was a good hit. I hit that much higher than last time.
The fire came quite close to them, and for a while they were in a highly dangerous situation.

word.entryDescription: taking long walks in the country
word.entryExample: Hiking in the mountains is what I like doing in my free time.

word.entryDescription: an area of high land smaller than a mountain
word.entryExample: They decided to go and look at an old castle on a hill.

word.entryDescription: used to refer to the male who is affected by an action when he also performs the action
word.entryExample: He's a goalkeeper and always hurting himself.

word.entryDescription: a very large African animal with short legs, a big head and a wide mouth that lives in and near water
word.entryExample: Hippos live in Africa.
